unittitle.value: Walter Rosenblum Unitarian Service Committee Papers

abstract.value: The collection includes personal papers, clippings, and ephemera documenting in a general way Walter Rosenblum's work for the Unitarian Service Committee in Toulouse and Saint-Jean de Luz, France (1946).

p.value: Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Naomi Rosenblum in 2009.  The accession number associated with this gift is 2009.013.

In the spring of 1946, the Unitarian Service Committee (USC) in Boston hired the American photographer
Walter Rosenblum (b. 1919) to document its extensive refugee relief work in Europe. In France, Rosenblum visited the USC rest home at St. Goin (Aquitane); the Walter B. Cannon Memorial Hospital and recreation center in
Toulouse; the Camp Clairac (Lot-et-Garonne) for underprivileged French and Spanish children; the Meillon Rest Home in Pau, which housed Spanish Nazi victims; and a summer camp and canteen in Les Andelys (Normandie). Starting in October, his photos began appearing regularly in the Unitarians' monthly magazine, the <emph render="italic">Christian Register</emph>. Rosenblum had been a U.S. Army Signal Corp combat photographer, and took the first motion picture footage of the Dachau concentration camp. Born in 1919 into a poor Jewish immigrant family living on New York's Lower East Side, in 1937 he joined the Film and Photo League, a Communist-associated popular front organization.

The collection includes personal papers, clippings, and ephemera documenting in a general way Walter Rosenblum's work for the Unitarian Service Committee in Toulouse and Saint-Jean de Luz, France (1946).
